verses.text: But Judas Maccabeus, and those with him, secretly entered the towns and summoned their kindred. They called together all those who remained faithful to their ancestral customs and gathered about six thousand men.
verses.comment: Judas Maccabeus emerges as a leader among those committed to the traditions of Israel. This highlights the importance of fidelity to the community's received faith, a theme continued in the new covenant (cf. Heb. 11:32-34). The gathering of the faithful remnant echoes other moments when God's people were preserved through small, faithful groups.

verses.text: They pleaded with the Lord to look upon the people who were oppressed by all and to have pity on the temple that was profaned by the ungodly, to have mercy on the city, now being destroyed and about to be leveled, and to hear the blood of those who cried out to Him.
verses.comment: The prayers for mercy focus on the people, the temple, and the city. The linking of the fate of the people with their place of worship points to the central role of liturgy and sacrifice. These themes are fulfilled in the new covenant, where the worship of God continues around Christ's once-for-all offering (Heb. 10:10-14).

verses.text: They prayed to God to hearken to the blood that cried out to him, to remember also the lawless destruction of innocent babies and the blasphemies committed against his name, and to show his hatred of evil.
verses.comment: The Jewish prayers appeal to God's justice, referencing innocent blood and blasphemy (echoing Genesis 4:10 and Psalm 79:5-7), underscoring a plea for divine response against atrocities perpetrated by the Seleucids.

verses.text: to remember also the lawless destruction of the innocent babies and the blasphemies committed against his name; and to show his hatred of evil.
verses.comment: The community joins in continuous prayer, foreshadowing the Christian tradition of corporate intercession (Acts 1:14). The restoration of the temple is intrinsically connected to the restoration of the people, suggesting the inseparability of right worship and right living.

verses.text: As soon as Maccabeus got his army organized, the Gentiles could not withstand him, for the wrath of the Lord had turned to mercy.
verses.comment: Here is another example of military achievement being attributed to divine favor. The narrative emphasizes God's mercy as the primary cause of victory—an important theological theme repeated in salvation history.

verses.text: Coming without warning, he would set fire to towns and villages. He captured strategic positions and put to flight not a few of the enemy.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes Judas Maccabeus’s tactical prowess in guerrilla warfare, employing surprise raids to defeat Seleucid forces. The reference to burning towns and taking key locations highlights the intensity and strategic importance of his actions, which contributed significantly to the morale and momentum of the Jewish revolt.

verses.text: Wherever Judas encountered any enemy detachment, he destroyed them, and especially at night he took advantage of his position. His fame spread everywhere.
verses.comment: Night raids indicate both practical strategy and God's mysterious intervention through unlikely means. Prudence and courage in defense of the faith play a key role in salvation history.

verses.text: When Philip saw how much progress Judas was making, and how rapidly he was growing in power, he wrote to Ptolemy, the governor of Coele-Syria and Phoenicia, to provide more support for the king's cause.
verses.comment: Philip's alarm and appeal to a higher authority illustrates human attempts to resist God's chosen leaders, a motif seen throughout the Old Testament.
verses.sectionHeader: Nicanor Plans to Destroy the Jews

verses.text: Ptolemy quickly selected Nicanor, son of Patroclus, one of the king’s chief friends, and assigned him over not fewer than twenty thousand Gentiles, instructing him to destroy the entire nation of Judea.
verses.comment: The overwhelming force raised against Judea mirrors many instances in Scripture where the people of God face seemingly impossible odds. Divine deliverance is foreshadowed.

verses.text: Nicanor intended to make a profit from the captives of the Jews to pay the tribute owed to the Romans.
verses.comment: The selling of one's people for tribute echoes Joseph's betrayal and anticipates the redemptive theme of ransom.

verses.text: So he sent messengers to the cities along the seacoast, inviting them to buy Jewish slaves and promising ninety slaves for every talent, without concern that the Lord had proclaimed judgment upon him.
verses.comment: Nicanor’s presumption in dealing with God’s people for his own mercenary gain is condemned by the Law; God’s justice ultimately prevails over the schemes of the wicked.

verses.text: When Judas learned of Nicanor’s advance, he informed his companions about the army’s approach.
verses.comment: Preparation in the face of adversity signals the necessity of courageous leadership among God's people.

verses.text: But some who were afraid, lacking faith in God's justice, slipped away.
verses.comment: Doubt and desertion have always been challenges faced by believers (see Jn. 6:66). The text reminds one of Christ's call to persevere in faith, even in the midst of trial.

verses.text: Others sold everything they had left, and with one accord urged the Lord to deliver those who had been wickedly sold by the ungodly.
verses.comment: Community solidarity and sacrificial giving are affirmed here, prefiguring later practices among Christians.

verses.text: They implored the Lord to rescue His people, who were being unjustly sold, and to not overlook the nation that always called upon His holy name.
verses.comment: This appeal to God’s covenant faithfulness resembles the prayers of Old Testament saints, emphasizing the sacramental mark of belonging to God’s People, fulfilled in the new covenant community.

verses.text: Judas called his men together and exhorted them not to fear the enemy, who were coming against them unjustly, but to trust in God, who would overthrow those who came against them with arrogance.
verses.comment: Judas’s encouragement closely parallels the exhortations given by Moses and Joshua, urging faith over fear. True leadership encourages hope in God’s providence.

verses.text: He exhorted them to keep before their eyes the impious outrage that the Gentiles had committed against the holy place, the torture of the mocked city, and also the destruction of their ancestral customs.
verses.comment: Judas calls his men to remember recent sacrileges and sufferings, invoking their zeal for the sanctity of the Temple and their heritage.

verses.text: For they trust in arms and in bold acts, but we trust in almighty God, who is able with a single nod to strike down those who are coming against us, and even the whole world if necessary.
verses.comment: This verse contrasts human power with divine sovereignty, reflecting a central theme of biblical faith in God's omnipotence (cf. Psalm 20:7; 1 Samuel 17:47), and affirms that victory, even against overwhelming odds, is dependent on God rather than military strength.

verses.text: Moreover, he told them of the occasions when help came to their ancestors; how, in the time of Sennacherib, when one hundred eighty-five thousand perished,
verses.comment: Steadfastness for the Law and temple foreshadows the later witness of the martyrs who were willing to die rather than abandon the faith given to them.

verses.text: He recounted the battle against the Galatians that took place in Babylonia, when eight thousand Jews fought along with four thousand Macedonians; and, when the Macedonians were hard-pressed, the Jews destroyed one hundred and twenty thousand Galatians and took great spoils, because of their trust in Him who gives victory.
verses.comment: The recounting of past deliverance, likely legendary, serves as encouragement of God's faithfulness in battle when His people trust Him (compare Judges 7; 1 Maccabees 5:34), reinforcing the motif that divine help secures victory over numerically superior foes.

verses.text: With these words he filled them with courage and made them ready to die for their laws and their country; then he divided his army into four parts.
verses.comment: Such self-sacrifice reminds one of the call to discipleship and laying down of one’s life for others, as taught by Christ (Jn. 15:13).

verses.text: He appointed his brothers also, Simon and Joseph and Jonathan, each to command a division, putting fifteen hundred men under each.
verses.comment: Leadership is entrusted to Judas’s brothers with explicit numbers, portraying an organized and familial structure for the rebel army. The division of forces into units of 1,500 reflects both the military strategy and the importance of kinship ties in leading the Jewish resistance at this critical moment.
verses.sectionHeader: The Defeat of Nicanor and the Enemies

verses.text: Besides, he appointed Eleazar to read aloud from the holy book, and gave the watchword, 'The help of God'; then, leading the first division himself, he joined battle with Nicanor.
verses.comment: Prayer for divine signs anticipates the role of miracles in confirming God’s word, a theme continued with Christ and His apostles (Mk. 16:20).

verses.text: With God’s help, they cut down more than nine thousand enemies, wounded and crippled most of the survivors, forcing them all to flee.
verses.comment: God’s help in military victory demonstrates that all deliverance ultimately comes from Him, not human effort alone.

verses.text: They captured the money of those who had come to buy them as slaves. After pursuing them for some distance, they were obliged to return because the hour was late.
verses.comment: Worship and thanksgiving follow God’s victory, in keeping with Old Testament tradition (see Ps. 136). Salvation leads to praise.

verses.text: It was the day before the sabbath, and for that reason they did not continue their pursuit.
verses.comment: Religious observance directly shapes military action, as the approach of the Sabbath causes the Jewish army to halt the chase. This reflects the tension—and integration—between the demands of sacred law and the necessities of warfare for the Maccabean community.

verses.text: When they had collected the arms of the enemy and stripped them of their spoils, they kept the sabbath, giving great praise and thanks to the Lord, who had preserved them for that day and allotted it to them as the beginning of mercy.
verses.comment: Theological interpretation is foregrounded: the Sabbath becomes not only a rest after battle but a celebration of divine favor and mercy. The act of collecting arms and spoils is coupled with worship and gratitude, indicating the intertwining of victory and religious identity for the Maccabees.

verses.text: After the Sabbath, they divided the spoil among the wounded, the widows, the orphans, and the rest among themselves and their families.
verses.comment: Distribution of goods to the needy closely anticipates the apostolic church’s care for widows and orphans. The link between worship and almsgiving is established.

verses.text: When they had accomplished these things, together with prayers, they asked the Lord, merciful and gracious, to be fully reconciled with His servants.
verses.comment: Here, prayer for ongoing reconciliation shows a deep sense of dependence on God’s mercy, pointing ahead to the fullness of reconciliation accomplished in Christ (2 Cor. 5:18-19).

verses.text: In encounters with the forces of Timothy and Bacchides they killed more than twenty thousand of them and got possession of some exceedingly high strongholds, and they divided a very large amount of plunder, giving to those who had been tortured and to the orphans and widows, and also to the aged, shares equal to their own.
verses.comment: Mercy and justice are demonstrated in the distribution of plunder to the vulnerable groups—those tortured, orphans, widows, and the elderly—underscoring the Maccabean commitment to communal care and equity, even amid military triumphs. This practice echoes key ethical priorities in Jewish tradition.

verses.text: They collected all the arms of the enemies and carefuly stored them in strategic locations, and brought the rest of the spoils to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The act of bringing offerings to Jerusalem prefigures the later centrality of bringing offerings as an act of worship, fulfilled in Christ's offering in the heavenly city.

verses.text: They killed the commander of Timothy’s forces, a most wicked man, and one who had greatly troubled the Jews.
verses.comment: This clarifies that it was a subordinate commander of Timothy, not Timothy himself, who was killed—a crucial distinction for historical accuracy regarding the events of the Maccabean revolt.

verses.text: While they were celebrating the victory in the city of their ancestors, they burned those who had set fire to the sacred gates, Callisthenes and some others, who had fled into one little house; so these received the proper reward for their impiety.
verses.comment: The death of Callisthenes, punished by fire for his sacrilege, illustrates the principle of divine retribution for blasphemy (cf. Leviticus 24:16), and affirms the sanctity of God's temple and the inevitability of justice.

verses.text: The thrice-accursed Nicanor, who had brought the thousand merchants to buy the Jews,
verses.comment: Those exalting themselves against God’s house ultimately find defeat, prefiguring the ultimate triumph of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Having been humbled with the help of the Lord by opponents whom he regarded as of the least account, Nicanor took off his splendid uniform and made his way alone like a runaway slave across the country until he reached Antioch, having succeeded chiefly in the destruction of his own army!
verses.comment: The enemy's humiliation emphasizes that victory and vindication ultimately come from God, not from human schemes.

verses.text: So he who had undertaken to secure tribute for the Romans by the capture of the people of Jerusalem proclaimed that the Jews had a Defender, and that therefore the Jews were invulnerable, because they followed the laws ordained by him.
verses.comment: Even the enemies of the faithful are forced to confess God’s power and that true security comes from fidelity to His commands—a lesson for all believers in every age.

sections.title: Nicanor Plans to Destroy the Jews
The Defeat of Nicanor and the Enemies
